intro: Paepalanthus comans, commonly known as the yellow-bellied sunflower, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its bright yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant typically grows in open, sunny areas such as grasslands and disturbed soils. It has a short stem with narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, tubular flowers that attract pollinators like bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it is not widely commercially available.
